thread.title: Bears try to put claws on SLC's top back
thread.title_full: Bears try to put claws on SLC's top back

author: David McCollum
title: Bears try to put claws on SLC's top back
text:
Bears try to put claws on SLC's top back Posted: October 23, 2015 - 10:38pm By David McCollum LOG CABIN STAFF WRITER 
Lamar’s Kade Harrington is the leading rusher in the Southland Conference, averaging 185 yards per game. The University of Central Arkansass’ Dominique Thomas is a distance second at 87. 
The challenge is obvious Saturday night in Beaumont, Texas, for the Bear defense, energized by a strong performance in a loss to McNeese State last week. 
“You just don’t stop the guy; you just try to slow him down,” said Northwestern State coach Jay Thomas, whose team defeated the Cardinals, 48-35, last week but yielded 282 yards on 36 carries and five touchdowns. “When he goes out of the game for a rest after getting 100 yards or so, you breathe a sigh of relief. Once he cracks the second level of defense and gets past the linebackers, I haven’t seen a defensive back who could catch him.” 
UCA coach Steve Campbell added, “He has tremendous vision and great cutback ability. He is hard to tackle; he breaks a lot of tackles and he has really good speed. He looks a step faster than last year. He gets into the open field and he hits a home run. 
“That offensive line can open holes and he doesn’t miss a cut.” 
“Our players were telling us last week, ‘Coach, we’re all around him trying to get him, .said Jay Thomas’” 
The Cardinals lost to Sam Houston State, 49-46, and to Southeastern Louisiana, 30-27. 
Campbell also says the Cardinals have a quarterback and wide receivers to add to a “pick your poison’ attack. 
Lamar coach Ray Woodard says his offensive line may be underrated. 
“They are not the greatest one-on-one players but out the five together and they just play well together.” 
But Woodard realizes there’s a challenge against the UCA defense, which held McNeese to 160 total yards last week. 
“It’s starts up front,” said Woodard. “They rotate a number of defensive linemen and they get those shoulder pads under you and get after you. The big thing is they can apply a lot of pressure with just four guys and that opens up a lot of things. Their linebackers know how to hit and run to the football and their secondary is smart, runs to the ball and are run-stoppers. 
“I like the way their team is built. Their offensive line is aggressive. They line up and bloody your nose. They have a two-headed monster.” 
And Woodard hs particular praise for UCA defensive end Jonathan Woodard. 
“I’d take him as a relative,” he said. “He’s not but I’d certainly take him.”
